testimony: Today we are starting with the application of Mr Vusi Sidney Mononi, application number AM7913/97.	  The panel consist of myself, Judge Khampepe, on my right hand side, Adv F. Bosman, on my left hand side, Mr Ilan Lax.  Who is appearing for the applicant?
Thank you Madam Chair.  I am Leopeng P.M., I am appearing on behalf of the applicant.
I am Thabile Thabete, the Evidence Leader for the TRC.
Mr Leopeng, are we in a position to commence?
Yes, Madam Chair, we are in a position to commence.
May we for the benefit of the members of the public, indicate that English is to be found in channel 2, Zulu, channel 3, and Shangaan in channel 4.  Thank you very much.  Mr Leopeng?
Is Mr Mononi going to take an oath?
Yes, I was going to indicate that I am not in a position to hand in a supplementary affidavit, I am just going to lead viva voce evidence of the applicant, Mr Mononi.
Yes.  Mr Mononi, will you please rise?
You have been duly sworn in, you may take a seat.  You may proceed Mr Leopeng.
Thank you Madam Chair.  Mr Mononi, you are the applicant in this application for amnesty and you are now serving a term of imprisonment at Medium C, Johannesburg prison, is that correct?

Is it further correct that on the 19th of April 1996, and at Witwatersand Local Division, you were convicted murder and five other charges and you were sentenced to an effective period of 24 years imprisonment?
Now Mr Mononi, on or before the incident that is the 4th of August 1993, to which political party did you belong?
Which offices did you hold within the ranks of the ANC?
I was a member and I was a sub-branch Organiser within the ANC Youth League and also a supporter of the SACP and I was a Commander of the Self Defence Unit.
You mentioned that you were the Commander of the SDU's, did you - were you trained to be a Commander of the SDU's and if so, when?
I underwent crash courses inside the country.
Who were your trainers during that training?
Rivert Mkhize, Veli Khumalo and other MK members who had been trained outside the country.
Now let's turn to the day in question, that is the 4th of August 1993.  Very briefly, tell the Committee what happened.

We were patrolling with other comrades on that day, patrolling at Mandela Village and it so happened that as we were patrolling, we came across two uniformed policemen and we approached these two policemen.
	We were armed with firearms, a Makarov pistol, a 38 Special and well as a palm gun and two hand grenades.  	I was in possession of a Makarov pistol at the time.
What were the reasons for you to patrol?

Mandela Village was such that the people thereof were attacked by the members of the IFP and the vigilante groups and they were also harassed generally by the police, so that we had to protect the people against these things.
On that day when you were patrolling, did you have instructions from above for you, to allow you to patrol the Mandela Squatter Camp?
From whom and what rank was he?
The person in charge that day was comrade Winki.
So, are you saying that Winki is the person who gave you instructions to go and patrol the Mandela Squatter Camp?
Yes, proceed from where you said that you were armed with these firearms, and you met the two police officials.

It so happened that we were deployed around the entrance of Mandela Village.  These two policemen in uniform arrived and we at the time, happened to go to them.  We pointed our firearms at them, and instructed them not to fight because we only wanted their firearms.
You said we, who do you refer to when you say we?
There were five of us, it was myself and other four comrades, comrade Winki, comrade Nyao Daniel and comrade Pat as well as Xolani.
Will you please repeat the names again.
Winki, Daniel, Pat as well as Xolani.  Myself included.
So among five of you, who was your Commander or the Unit Commander?
Sorry Mr Leopeng, sorry to intrude.  My arithmetic implies that there were six of them.  He has given us five names plus himself?  Winki, Nyao, Daniel, Pat, Xolani and himself?
Daniel and Nyao are one person.
Okay.  That is helpful, thank you.
Thank you.  Proceed from where you said you met these two police officials and you told them you are not fighting with them, and that they must hand their firearms to you.

It so happened that one of the police threw himself to the ground and the other one, tried to fight Xolani who was in possession of a palm gun, he was trying to grab the palm gun and a shot was fired in the process.  I saw him later on laying on the ground, having been shot.
	We took the firearm and we fled, his service pistol.
So is that your evidence that the police official who was shot, was shot by a bullet which was fired from the firearm which was in possession of Xolani?

Isn't that leading Mr Leopeng?  Isn't that a leading statement?  You have not established that evidence.  Ask an appropriate question that will not be leading, but which will nevertheless enable him to give that kind of evidence.

I beg your pardon, Madam Chair.
	Just tell this Committee actually what killed the said police official?
It so happened that as they were wrestling over the firearm, a shot went off and the police fell.
Who was wrestling with who?  You say it so happened that as they were wrestling, who is he referring to?
I am referring to Xolani and this other one policeman who happened to be shot later on.
Did you witness the whole incident?
I only saw this other police falling on the ground after the shot went off.  He apparently was shot on the chest.
Yes, because after comrade Xolani pointed the firearm at him, at the police, the police tried to grab the firearm.
Thank you Madam Chair.  After you noticed the said police official falling down with a gun wound, what happened thereafter?
After that, one of our comrades took his firearm and we fled.  The other police managed to flee uninjured.

Won't you try when you give your evidence, because there were only five of you, won't you try instead of referring to a person as a particular, I mean as one comrade, just mention his name.  Will you do that as you give your evidence?
The one person I am referring to here, is Pat.  He is the one who took the firearm from the police who had fallen down.
Thank you Madam Chair.  After you fled, then what happened?  What happened to the firearm which one Pat took from the police official who fell on the ground?
We took the firearm along because our intention was to get the firearm.
Why do you say that your intention was to get the firearm, what prompted you to go and look for the firearms?
We were trying to gather weapons for the defence of the people, weapons such as firearms, so that our strategy as SDU's was to disarm the police.
You said your strategy was to disarm the police.  What were you going to do with these weapons that you disarmed the police officials of?
We were going to use the firearms to defend the community against attacks by Inkatha and vigilantes and other people who were troubling the community.
Was your action to disarm the police official, authorised by the Overall Commander of the SDU's?
Yes, that is correct because the idea was to reinforce within the structures of the SDU's.

If I just for a  while go back to the evidence that you had given, you said that on that day you were patrolling in the Mandela Squatter Camp, so are you telling this Court that during the patrol, you deemed it necessary to disarm the police official, or that was within your instructions again during the patrolling?
It was an order that had already been issued, that if we happened to see policemen in the area, we should disarm them to reinforce.
Where did this order come from?
This order was issued by comrade Winki who was in charge for the patrols on that day.
If I go back, who was this comrade Winki that you are referring to, was he an ANC member or what was his rank within the ANC if I may just ask you?
He was a member of the ANC as well as a member of MK.  He was a Commander of the Unit within the structures of the SDU's.
So he was your superior, you were under his command on that day, to patrol and to disarm the police officials, is that correct?
Now tell this Committee, what was your political objective that you wanted to achieve during the patrol and during the process of disarming police officials?
Our objective was to augment on the firearms that we had, so as to be able to defend the community against the IFP and the vigilante attacks.
Was the ANC office in Diepkloof aware of the activities of the SDU's and the command of comrade Winki regarding the patrolling and the disarming of police officials?

You said in your evidence that your intention was to disarm the said two police officials.  Did you intend during the patrolling or during the process of disarming to kill anybody in disarming the police officials?
No, our objective was not to kill.  We were just intent on robbing them of their firearms.
Are you now telling this Committee that you are sorry that the deceased died during your ...
Mr Leopeng, please try and contain your leading.  He hasn't said anything about what he feels or thinks about this matter.  You are putting words in his mouth.
I beg your pardon.  What do you feel about the whole incident on the 4th of August 1993?
It makes me feel sad.  Our intention was not to kill, but to get the firearms.  That so happened and I don't feel good about that.
Now tell us, what happened to the other four comrades that you are referring to, that is Nyao, Pat, Xolani and Winki?
After the integration, comrade Winki was now stationed here in Johannesburg where he was a policeman, he died last year.  Other comrades ended up joining the army and others are still around.

Can you be a little bit more specific?  I think that is what your Counsel is wanting you to do.
	Who did what and where are they today?
Winki died last year.  He was a police.  Pat is in the army, I don't know where he is stationed.  I have lost contact with comrade Xolani, Daniel is still around.
Tell us briefly, what active role did you play during the disarming of the said two police officials at which one died?
I was part of the whole thing.  I was armed with a pistol, but after this Peter took the firearm and we fled.
So that day your role was that you were armed and you opposed these two officials, is that the only thing that you did?
Lastly, why - let me rephrase the question, after you achieved the objective of disarming the police official, what were your intentions to do with the said firearm?

Hasn't that ground already been covered Mr Leopeng, unless you are trying to get new evidence, we already have evidence in that regard.  It was to augment the weapons that the SDU had, which they intended to use in order to protect the community against attacks by the IFP and other people, against the community.
Thank you Madam Chair.  I will leave the question.  How can you justify the act that you committed together with other comrades on the 4th of August 1993?
Hasn't that been covered by your questions when you questioned him on his political objective?
I beg your pardon, I will also leave that question.  I have no further questions.

May I just before Ms Thabete comes in, just clear something up Madam Chair.  Mr Leopeng, if you could just have a look at paragraph 9(a) on page 219, you haven't led any evidence specifically as to which acts your client is applying for amnesty.
	Is it that only covered in 9(a)(i)?
Yes, I think so, but let me lead him on that.
AS you do so, have regard to the sentence which was imposed by His Honourable Justice Levison.
Mr Mononi, you are here before this Committee to apply for amnesty for what act that you committed?
What specifically do you apply for?  You apply for amnesty for a specific act that you committed on the 4th of August 1993?

Sorry Mr Leopeng, before you tie your client down to a specific thing, amnesty may be sought for an act, an omission, an offence or a delict.  He may be applying in respect of offences, he may be applying in respect of acts, we don't know.
	I think before you tie your client down to a particular act, maybe just think about the position and then put the question to him.
Mr Leopeng, have you had an occasion to study the judgement of Judge Levison?

And in the light of that judgement, and in the light of the instructions that you have already obtained from Mr Mononi, you may be able to advise us without having to ask your client in respect of which acts he is seeking amnesty.  You may just tell us without having to lead his evidence in that regard.

Well Madam Chair, my difficulty is that as already consulted with the applicant and as already he gave evidence, he is not the one who shot the deceased.  He is applying for amnesty for solely the purpose, the common purpose.
Yes, he was convicted of murder, his evidence is that he was there even though he did not fire a shot that led to the killing of the policeman concerned.
Yes, that is true and that is what he is applying amnesty for.
Yes, so can you just tell us which acts or offences he is seeking amnesty for.
He is seeking amnesty for the murder and the robbery of the service pistol of the deceased.

He was convicted of attempted robbery, not robbery.  If you look at page 38 on the issue of sentence, you will see where he is sentenced in respect of what offences he has been convicted of.  It is neatly set out there.
The applicant is seeking amnesty on all offences that he was convicted of.
And you are aware that he did not confine himself of course, to offences for which he was convicted.  He may apply for amnesty in respect of acts or offences for which there was no conviction.
Yes.  Do you want us to take an adjournment to enable you to apply your mind in this regard?

Yes.  Obviously bearing in mind the fact that the reason why he was convicted of attempted robbery, was because on the evidence that was before Justice Levison, there was no indication that the firearm of the policeman who was subsequently killed, not Mr Nkuna, I am trying to get the name of the deceased, Mr Mathonsi, the evidence was that Mr Mathonsi's firearm was not in fact taken by the applicant, and his assailants.
	I am just drawing your attention to that fact.  We will take a short adjournment and we will reconvene at twenty past eleven.  Thank you.

(continued)   Thank you Madam Chair.  I wish to go back to the question from the panel on specific acts that he committed which he is applying amnesty for.
May I just not lead the applicant therein and just tell the panel on what is he applying for?

Thank you Madam Chair.  The applicant is applying for amnesty on count 1, that is the count of murder, count 2, attempted robbery, count 3, 4 and 5, unlawful possession of ammunition, shotgun and the hand grenades and also he is applying for amnesty for count 6, which he was not convicted of.
	The applicant in his evidence in chief stated that one Pat took the service pistol off the deceased, and he ran away.  He still maintains that version, even if he was not convicted of and he is applying for amnesty for that taking of the policeman's service firearm.
He therefore cannot apply for attempted robbery, is it attempted robbery in respect of the firearm of Mr Nkuna?
And the robbery of Mr Mathonsi's firearm?
Yes, that is so Madam Chair.  He is applying for robbery of that firearm and for the attempted robbery of the firearm of Mr Nkuna.
Nkuna being the policeman who was not killed?

That being the case, I think your evidence in chief, is lacking in only one material aspect, and that is with regard to where the firearms that were in possession of the applicant and his colleagues, were obtained.  You haven't led evidence in that regard and before you close your evidence in chief, we would like to hear you in that regard.
	You would have to give us evidence with regard to where the weapons which were in the possession of the applicant and his colleagues, were obtained.  Can you do that?

Thank you Madam Chair for your assistance.
	Now Mr Mononi, on that day you said specifically, you were armed with a Makarov pistol and the other comrades were armed with hand grenades, pump gun and a .38 revolver.  Where did you get such arms and ammunition?
These were firearms belonging to the Unit, they were given to us by the Commander of the Unit.  These were firearms belonging to the community.
Do you have an idea where did the Unit get these firearms which were handed to you on that day?
Some of the firearms were obtained as a result of the community having raised funds to purchase them and some of these firearms, were obtained by way of disarming the police.

Madam Chair, through your permission, I want to go back to the evidence that he gave regarding the taking of the firearm from the deceased.
	You said one Pat took the service pistol belonging to the deceased, where did he take that service pistol off the deceased?
This firearm, I would say after every operation or mission, we would go back and report to the Commander of the Unit and hand over the firearms.
So are you saying that that firearm was handed to the SDU or the Unit?
No further questions Madam Chair.  I now close the evidence of the applicant.
Yes, when he refers to the Commander of the Unit, he is referring to Winki?
When you refer to the Commander of the Unit, are you referring to Winki with whom you were on that day?
Yes, you are now through with your evidence in chief?  Are you through?
Yes, I am through.  I have one other witness.

Yes, but before you can do so, I think an opportunity should be given to Ms Thabete the Evidence Leader, to put questions to Mr Mononi about his evidence and an opportunity will then be given to the members of the Committee to put questions to Mr Mononi, whereafter you may then call your further witness to support his application, thank you.

Thank you Madam Chair.

I cannot recall as to how he was standing in relation to the other.

Ms Thabete, do you mean Mr Mononi or do you mean an order was given by one of his colleagues, you mean he gave the order?

Did they hand over the firearms?
Did anyone drop their guns down?

I saw blood stains on his chest as he was laying down, that is what I am saying.
Mr Mononi, it is my instruction that Mr Mathonsi as I have stated before, was standing at the back and he was actually shot from the back, right through, I mean ...

Yes, thank you, thank you, I was short of words, yes, exactly.  What is your comment on that?
I would not know what the entry point of the bullet was.  I only saw this injury on his chest.
But it was your evidence that you actually saw this, you witnessed the struggle.  Would you know why he was shot at the back maybe?
No, I would not know because the last time I witnessed this happening, it was when they were struggling for the firearm.  I cannot therefore say how he was shot from the back.

What I can say here is that when we arrived, I ended up or should I say I lastly saw one of these policemen falling down.  The other one wanted to grab the firearm from Xolani and that is when the shot went off.
So are you saying that it is not correct, it is Mr Nkuna who actually struggled with you and not the deceased?  Sorry who struggled with Xolani and not the deceased?
It was the deceased who was struggling with ... (tape ends) ...
Are your instructions that Mr Nkuna knew who Xolani was?
How can you put it to Mr Mononi that Mr Nkuna will say that Xolani struggled with him?
No Madam Chair, I said is it his evidence that Xolani struggled with the deceased and not with Mr Nkuna?
Yes, I wasn't putting it to him.
No, I was just asking him.

Okay.  Maybe I can clarify Madam Chair, my instructions are that it is not the deceased who struggled with any of the attackers, but it was actually Mr Nkuna himself.
	With regards to the service pistol that was taken from Mr Mathonsi, did you actually see Pat taking the service pistol from Mr Mathonsi, the deceased?
Where did he take it from?
It was on a holster, on the side of his waist.
It was on a holster, or in a holster on the side of his waist, around his waist.

It is also my instructions Mr Mononi, that none of you took the service pistol from the holster, the deceased's holster, but it is the policemen who came after the incident, who removed  the deceased's service pistol.  What is your comment to that?

The deceased was killed by Xolani, was shot by Xolani, not myself.

Sorry, I mean after the deceased had been shot, what happened thereafter?  Did you leave the scene, what happened, were you there when the policemen came?  Can you just briefly tell us what happened thereafter?
When the police arrived, we had already left, because after the police was shot, and another one had fled, we too left.  We fled.
Since my instructions are that you fled because Mr Nkuna was trying to struggle with you, would you say that is a correct statement?
No, we fled after this policeman had been shot, he was then laying on the ground.  The other policeman had fled to a different direction.

Thank you Madam Chair, no further questions.

Thank you Ms Thabete.  Mr Lax?
Thank you Chairperson.  Mr Mononi, did you not see any of your colleagues wrestling or struggling with the policeman who didn't die, Mr Nkuna?
No.  This one policeman lay down at the time.

	You will see at about line 14, he hears the explosive sound of a firearm, his attention becomes drawn to the deceased, trying to run away and his conclusion was that the sound heard by him, was the sound of a shot, only one shot.
	According to him, someone was standing there, holding a firearm, a shotgun pointed in the direction of the deceased.  He says two other persons were also present, one of those had a firearm.
	This person was trying to shoot at him.  The other person was attempting to remove his firearm from his holster, he resisted, he pushed up the hand of one of his attackers.  That hand held the firearm and a shot went off.
	These two men were standing on each side of him.  It appears the Inspector was holding his firearm in his own holster, so that the shot that went off, came from the firearm of one of the attackers.  He fell to the ground, then got an opportunity to remove his firearm from his holster and when he pulled it out, all three the attackers ran away.
	You say that didn't happen that way?
Yes, it did not happen that way.
Well then, what did this other policeman do, not the deceased, the other policeman?  Did anyone shoot at him?
No, only one shot was fired that day.  Nobody else attempted to shoot the other police.
Did no one try to take his firearm away from him?
There is one person who attempted to do that, but at that time, he was laying down.  That was after this other policeman had been shot and we fled.
So, when you told this man, or when Winki told the man these two men, to give you their firearms, what happened after that?

We pointed our firearms at them and the deceased was in front of Xolani.  He tried to grab Xolani and on pointing the firearm to the other policeman, this policeman lay down and after that, a gunshot went off.

How did he lay down, that is what we are interested in?  Did he just lay himself down flat on the ground, did he fall down, did somebody hit him on the head, what happened, you were there, you must tell us?
He threw himself on the ground.
Was that as the shot went off?

I pointed my firearm at them.
I was standing in the middle of them, covering my other comrades.

It was possible, because I was watching for anybody who could draw his firearm first, in case my comrades did not notice that.

It was Daniel, but we were not prosecuted together.  He was acquitted before the trial.
Yes, Daniel Dabula, Dabula is the surname.
And Lawrence Khumalo, which one is he?
Lawrence Khumalo was a member of the Unit, but he was not present on the crime scene, he was one of the people I was arrested with.
What are these people's names that were with you, what is Winki's name?
Winki is the name, I do not know the surname, Maponya is his combat name.
Pat is the name, I don't know the surname.
In your trial, you gave a completely different version of what happened on that day - you said you weren't there at all.
The evidence in court, could not have been the same as the evidence before this Commission, because in court I was not supposed to tell the truth.
The Court accepted a confession that you made to the police, do you remember that?
In that confession, was detail of you pointing out some, you took the home to one Martha Marole, do you remember that?
How did you know that the firearms were there?
A few firearms were there, I knew that.
The question was how did you know that?
These were places that we were using for dead letter boxes.

In your statement to the police, you gave the names of four other people that were with you.  Do you remember that if you look at page 26 of the judgement, the extract is there Mr Leopeng.  He mentioned the name of Nau, another name Zelani, Winki and Lawrence.
Nau is Daniel, Winki as well as Xolani.  Lawrence is one person with whom I was arrested, he was a member of the Unit, but he was not on the scene of the crime.
The question I am asking is, why did you give the names of your comrades in that statement?
On writing this statement, I must say that I was being beaten up and forced to admit.  I had to include Lawrence because he is the one with whom I was arrested.
I see.  You have said that you were a Commander of a sub-unit within the SDU, is that right?
How did it happen that your Commander went along with you, even though you were a Commander of a sub-unit of that Unit?
He was present on that day.  I could only be responsible if he was present, and I would be the one in those circumstances, to step in.
I think there was an error in your translation, he would have been responsible had he not been present.
Meaning he would have taken command had the Commander of the Unit been present.
Thank you Chair, I have no further questions, I have covered everything for myself.
I have no questions, thank you Chair.
I have no questions either.  Mr Leopeng, emanating from the questions by Ms Thabete and by Mr Lax, do you have anything to re-examine Mr Mononi in?

What is your response to that?
